questions.question_text: Which Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) service is best suited for running serverless apps?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
B is the correct answer
B is the correct answer.
Correct

questions.answer_description:
Oracle Cloud Infrastructure File Storage Service is a persistent, shared file system in Oracle Cloud. It provides a durable, scalable, distributed, enterprise-grade network file system. Oracle Cloud Infrastructure File Storage Service supports Network File System version 3.0 (NFSv3) and Network Lock Manager (NLM) for file locking functionality.
Reference:
https://docs.oracle.com/en/solutions/learn-storage-options-cloud/design-learn-shared-storage-options-oracle-cloud-infrastructure.html#GUID-
2E07B558-27CA-41B5-A142-D159560A82A4

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C-File Storage

keyword is 'file system'
Local NVMe- Block based(and cannot be shared across instances/its temporary storage)

Archive Storage- Object Storage (Object storage is HTTP based and technically it can be accessed by any compute instance ;and by multiple at same time)

Object Storage- object based(unstructured),can be accessed across multiple instances

Block Volume- Block Storage/can now be accessed across multiple instances using volume access type= read/write,shareable
C is correct answer

questions.question_text: Which Oracle Cloud Infrastructure storage service can provide a shared file system across multiple compute instances?
What does compute instance horizontal scaling mean?

choices.C: backing up data to object storage

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Horizontal scaling=adding more compute instances(servers) ,usually of same type

Vertical scaling=adding more compute power(RAM, storage,etc) to single instance
A is correct

A is correct.
https://docs.oracle.com/en/solutions/oci-best-practices/manage-changes-demand1.html#GUID-FBE50E2A-F970-4B8F-A8E7-F428B1C865C0 precises : “Horizontal scaling mean adding more compute instances for your workload.”
A is the correct answer.

questions.question_text: Which statement accurately describes an Oracle Cloud Infrastructure Region?

discussion.content: Regions are made up of ADs, ADs, have 3 FDs each. Question is misleading when asking about regions. No answer deals with directly with regions. Only one answer is correct. A

Selected Answer: A
Region:
Localized geographic area,comprised of one or more Availability Domains (AD).

Alternatively,it is a set of datacenters deployed within a latency defined perimeter and connected through a dedicated regional low-latency network

Availability Domain(AD):
-Each Domain is made up of one or more datacentres equipped with independent power, cooling and networking.
ie Domain 1 has DCs which have separate power from DCs in Domain 2

Fault Domains(FD):
within an AD,
-VMs placed in different fault domain implies they have different underlying server rack

described as Grouping of hardware and infrastructure within an Availability Domain to
provide anti affinity.
(aka logical data center)

========
A-correct

B-incorrect,instead A is correct

C-the reverse is true, each AD has multiple FD.

D-correct statement would be -Each region has atleast one AD.
(Not all Regions have multiple AD)
The only correct statement is A, regardless the question.
question is not clear
A is more correct

choices.C: Each Fault Domain has multiple Availability Domains.
choices.B: Each Availability Domain has a single Fault Domain.
choices.D: Each region has a single Fault Domain.
choices.A: Each Availability Domain has three Fault Domains.

choices.B: Capital Expenditure to Operational Expenditure conversion

discussion.content: Increased Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) i.e A

Selected Answer: A
Answer is A

Selected Answer: A
A is the obvious answer

A et B are correct answers.
In fact, increasing TCO is not beneficial to a Company.
Same for converting CAPEX to OPEX. Most of the CAPEX can be amortized and is deductible (tax) while OPEX is an operational cost that you can't deduct in most of the cases.
Conclusion: The question has 2 correct answers.

comments.content: OPEX is completly deductible and you have no upfront COSTrade like CAPEX. So b is wrong.

Which is NOT a valid business benefit for a customer considering migrating their infrastructure and apps to Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI)?
Notice the "NOT" Keyword, CAPES TO OPEX is one of the OCI Migration befits.

discussion.content: Answer is A
